title: 103_s1904
content:
The "Board of Veterans' Appeals Administrative Procedures Improvement Act of 1994" amends the number of members on the Board of Veterans' Appeals and imposes ethical and legal limitations on the Chairman, similar to judges of the United States Court of Veterans Appeals. The amendment to subsection (c) of section 7101 of title 38, United States Code, allows the Chairman to designate employees as acting members of the Board for up to 90 days. An acting member can continue to serve beyond the designated period for specific proceedings, but not for more than 270 days in a year. The amendment allows the Chairman to designate employees as acting members of the Board for up to 90 days, with a limit of 270 days in a year. The number of acting members cannot exceed 20% of the total Board members. Amendments also include changes to subsections (e) and (d)(3)(B) of section 7101 of title 38, United States Code. SEC. 5. CHAIRMAN'S ANNUAL REPORT ON BOARD ACTIVITIES.

Amends Section 7101(d)(2) of title 38, United States Code to include reporting on the number of employees designated as acting members of the Board and their participation in cases during the year.

SEC. 6. DECISIONS BY THE BOARD.

Amends Sections 7102 and 7103 of title 38, United States Code regarding the assignment of members of the Board. Sec. 7102 of title 38, United States Code allows for the assignment of proceedings before the Board to individual members or panels of at least three members. The assigned member or panel makes determinations and issues a final report. The Chairman cannot be assigned as an individual member but can participate in proceedings assigned to a panel. Sec. 7103 allows for reconsideration and correction of obvious errors. The Board's decision under section 7102 of title 38 is final unless the Chairman orders reconsideration. Upon such an order, the case is referred to a panel for review, ensuring a fair process. The panel must not include members involved in the original decision and must review the entire record before making a new decision. The Board's decision is final unless the Chairman orders reconsideration. A panel reviews the entire record and makes a decision by majority vote, which becomes the final decision of the Board. The Board can correct obvious errors in the record on its own motion. Section 7107 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include procedures relating to appeals, including dockets and hearings. Each case received for appeal is considered in regular order on the docket. Cases may be advanced for earlier consideration with valid reasons. The appellant must be given a hearing before the Board decides on the appeal. Formal recorded hearings are conducted by designated Board members. An appellant may request a hearing before the Board at its principal location or a Department facility. Hearings are scheduled based on the order of requests received, unless the appellant is seriously ill or facing financial hardship. The Secretary may provide facilities and equipment to the Board upon request. The appellant can participate in a hearing before the Board through electronic means if suitable facilities and equipment are available. This option is equivalent to a personal hearing and must be conducted in the same manner. If the appellant declines this option, they still have the opportunity for a hearing as provided. The appellant's opportunity for a hearing before the Board is not affected if suitable equipment is available for an electronic hearing. The item in the table of sections is amended to include details about appeals and hearings. Section 7104(a) of title 38, United States Code, is amended by removing the third sentence and correcting a cross-reference. Section 7110 is repealed, and the table of sections is updated accordingly. Additionally, there is a revision to income verification requirements. Parents DIC and Pension sections of title 38, United States Code are amended to allow for discretionary actions instead of mandatory ones, and to specify reporting requirements for a calendar year. The Parents DIC and Pension sections of title 38, United States Code are amended to allow discretionary actions and specify reporting requirements for a calendar year. Amendments include replacing "file a revised report" with "notify the Secretary," removing "estimated" where it appears, and eliminating "such applicant's or recipient's estimate of."
